turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about North Sea Radio Orchestra.
turn.1: What is meant by North Sea Radio Orchestra's return to form?
turn.2: North Sea Radio Orchestra really should be smug, boring and irrelevant.
turn.3: What did critics say about the new material?
turn.4: So how do they make this stuff so exciting?
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: > The third NSRO album sees Craig and Sharron Fortnam changing tack in subtle but significant ways.
turn.7: What were some of the ways they changed their tack?
turn.8: The old poets have been sidelined in favour of self-penned lyrics that neatly reflect their very English sense of melody and the female Fortnam's light, sad, pretty, folkie-meets-chorister voice.
turn.9: Did the new material sound good?
turn.10: The title-track, with its spooked electronic music box feel, provides the lines that define the mood: "I a moon orbiting myself / Sometimes gravity pull me close.
turn.11: What was the most interesting thing about the article?
turn.12: " The words throughout the album feel like the thoughts of someone so outside of the real world that they can hover above themselves, watching their own futile attempts to connect, like a child watching ants and pondering whether to drown them.
